import React from "react"; import { useState } from "react"; import BudgetChart from "./BudgetChart"; import NavBar from "./Navbar"; import "../styles/Budget.css"; function Budget() { const [newIncome, setNewIncome] = useState(1000); const [newNeeds, setNewNeeds] = useState(50); const [newWants, setNewWants] = useState(30); const [newFinancialGoals, setNewFinancialGoals] = useState(20); var totalPercentage = newNeeds + newWants + newFinancialGoals; return ( <>

Budget Pie Chart

{totalPercentage === 100 && newNeeds > 0 && newNeeds < 100 && newFinancialGoals > 0 && newFinancialGoals < 100 && newWants > 0 && newWants < 100 && newIncome >= 0 ? ( ) : (

Total Percentage is not 100%!

)}
setNewIncome(event.target.value)} readonly class="total-input form-control" />
Percentage of allocations in your Budget
setNewNeeds(event.target.value)} readonly class="total-input form-control" />
setNewWants(event.target.value)} readonly class="total-input form-control" />
setNewFinancialGoals(event.target.value)} readonly class="total-input form-control" />

50-30-20 Budget Rule

Popularised by Elizabeth Warren, this rule acts as a rule of thumb in helping you to allocate your budget in three categories: Needs, Wants and Financial goals.{" "}

Needs

  • Rent
  • Groceries
    •

    Wants

  • Entertainment Services
  • Hobbies

    • Financial Goals

  • Savings
  • Investment

    • {" "} As with all budgetting rules out there, this is only a rough guide and you can make your own adjustments to better suit your needs!{" "}

    ); } export default Budget;
